title: I wanna get over with k-pop addiction. How can I get over with it? - Quora

response.answer_text: I myself am a Kpop fan I don’t obsess over it I listen to lots of songs in different languages and I don’t plan leaving the fandom any time soon maybe when I’m older but here are my tips on how to stop. Delete every picture of your bias and group from your phone So every Kpop fan has some pictures of their bias or idols on their phone maybe as a lock/home screen. I have about 5 tiny compared to other right? Anyway delete all them and distance yourself from them.Remove Kpop things from your Instagram Feed If you have Instagram you should do this one. I have two Instagram accounts, a fan account & a personal one. My personal one has no Kpop in it whatsoever but my fan account is full of Kpop and a little bit of Western celebrities. Anyway when you see something Kpopish that comes up on your feed click on not interested and remove Kpop from your suggestion list and remove Kpop from your suggestion list. Don’t remove everything leave a little just not a lot.Do other things Okay even sometimes I like spending hours looking at memes and opinions and different groups but stop. Do something else go out, go for a walk or just read anything that will distract you for a while.Listen to other songs You can listen to some Kpop songs but try to keep it less. When I first got into Kpop my playlist was 95% Kpop 5% other. However it’s gone down and now my playlist has changed 60% Kpop 35% English 5% Other. Still really high Kpop but it’s an improvement. Try listening to songs other than Kpop and have s good balance.Stop believing you will get married to your “Oppa” To daydream is one thing I admit I have daydreamed about meeting them but never marrying them, but if you do stop. I’m guessing your not Korean can’t speak Korean or don’t live in Korea you will most likely be extremely lucky to even see them in concert forget talking to them.If you start wishing you were Korean or show at signs of becoming a Koreaboo STOP Now even at one point I started thinking what must it be like to live in Korea? And then I realised that was a warning sign I was like what the fuck snap out of it! Obviously they weren’t major thoughts I didn’t wish I was korean but I was afraid I’d be labelled as a Koreaboo when I’m not so I cut down my Kpop time and those thoughts went away eventually. Be happy with who you are.Realise not every Korean person looks like an Idol I’m not gonna lie when I was first this naive girl who got into Kpop I was like are all Koreans this good looking? Because I never saw an ugly idol and then I realised that not every Korean looks like that. Some idols have PS some don’t but most idols bleach their skin and do their eyes and do extreme diets. In Korea I’m pretty sure almost all products have bleaching properties. Most Korean people don’t look like that okay? Every race, skin colour, background, ethnicity and religion is beautiful not just one.Realise how insecure it makes people feel I’m pretty sure most not all people have thought wow their bodies are so thin how do they keep it that way?! I myself have thought this and have extreme dieted I don’t want to look korean or be Korean I just wanted a thin body like idols. If it makes international fans feel that way imagine how it makes Koreans people. Korea is already so harsh on looks young students get PS sometimes and starve themselves.Kpop is not perfect and is sometimes dark This is something every Kpop fan should know. Idols go on harsh diets to maintain their bodies or else Knetizens will hate on them. They feel so insecure and feel the need to work so much they barely sleep. There are stalkers and saesangs who are creepy af and haters I can’t imagine the type of life Kpop idols live. Some entertainment companies such as SM work their idols and trainees to the death. There used to be and sometimes still are slave contracts and some girs are molested idols are blackmailed and blacklisted by their company.You don’t know an idol personally or what they actually do An idol as to live up to their innocent image. But most will probably masterbate, drink, watch porn (not all), be intrigued by the member of the opposite sex or engage in sexual activities. Live with it it’s their life.Kpop can be extremely fake Like another person said sometimes not all the time but sometimes Kpop can be fake. The way an idol act can be scripted and fake. Like if your are going to debut in a group your company will tell you to take on the role of the evil maknae. Or to be the happy cheerful member but behind the cameras you won’t always smile and will go through hard days.Kpop isn’t your life Don’t become that type of perosn that is hell bent on going to Kpop concerts, travelling to Korea spends all their money on tickets and Kpop merch and looks down on Western music and only prefers Korean music. There is more to life Kpop is just a little hobby.You will slowly lose interest as you grow older I think I will too maybe I’ll listen to a few songs but I won’t stan any groups I’ll probably get sick of the cheesy lyrics about love.The sad truth is your favourite idol may like you because your a fan but they don’t actually know you and you won’t be important to them At the end of the day your just someone who supports them and gives them money nothing more.You don’t have to give up Kpop just don’t obsess over it and just see it as another genre not a life style

Live in South Korea and assimilate into Korean society. I was once a big kpop fan. Then I had a chance to live there. Every day you see people with almost the same features as the artists. Every day you see billboards and advertisements of Korean artists. Every day you hear their music. Every day you hear their language. Every day you’re in Korea. Must be a dream come true, huh? It started to die down on me when I began to realize that for Koreans, kpop is only for middle and high schoolers. It’s a child thing. Something to scream about. Something to spend your free time on when you’re young and carefree. After that it becomes something corny. Even uncool. Something that adults (or people who consider themselves adults) just wouldn’t do—there are so much more important things to think about. And then you hear stories about how hard kpop artists work. Like no-sleeping-at-night-till-you-perfect-the-dance-routine hard. Like putting-up-with-the-whims-of-your-superiors-without-a-say hard. Like worrying-about-what-other-people-think-about-you-all-the-time hard. Like having-to-do-long-overtime-hours-every-single-day-and-then-still-have-to-drink-with-the-boss-and-colleagues-till-dawn hard. Then the day after that it’s still-have-to-go-to-work-at-eight-in-the-morning hard. But then it’s also work-that-barely-pays-you-you’d-wonder-if-it’s-even-worth-it hard. And it’s also every-day-press-repeat-it’s-all-just-too-exhausting hard. You believe all these stories about kpop because it happens to you. It happens to your friend. It happens to almost every single person you meet. This kind of hard is the norm. And then you realize you obsess so much about kpop because they show you exactly what you want to see. A world that is almost perfect. A world that is all pretty and handsome. A world full of glitters and flicker and flash of a thousand lights. The high life. But then k-world’s reality is not perfect at all. It’s almost as if someone suddenly poured cold water on you and you grasp for breath and then it all sinks in. This is reality. This is ‘Hell Joseon’. There is no perfect. Would you still be obsessing over the same old imperfect world you’ve been living in all your life? I don’t think so. P.S. I still like korean music. But I prefer indie music now. And some ballads/acoustics/duets.
